title: Are Apple users less tech savvy? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m a software engineer, and I absolutely prefer Mac OS and Apple products. The reason is actually because MacOS has much more utility than Windows, and far more potential for user innovation. Not the other way around like you mention. Admittedly, I like some Linux distros, but as far as Windows is concerned, it’s the poorest design and least functional OS out there. You may need to specifically mention what you mean I guess, but my first reaction is that the truth is the opposite of what you’re describing. For example, Mac OS is the only OS on the market that I can run Windows, Linux and Mac OS side by side in VMs. That one fact, pretty much disproves your theory that it’s less functional. It means there is nothing you can’t do on a Mac that you can do in the other operating systems you mentioned. There is no official, or even reliable way to do that on a Windows machine, and would require you to break Apple’s licensing model which is a barrier that can’t be overcome in a business environment. Ditto Linux for that matter. Also, Mac OS is designed much better than Windows. The designers at Windows made some really poor decisions a long time ago, and are now stuck with them. The registry is probably the worst one. It’s a database, that presents itself as a filesystem like, thing. It has totally proprietary datatypes, and because there is no real standard where 3rd party developers are supposed to place settings, it’s a scatter-brained mess. The registry is also the culprit that requires all Windows apps to be installed, and as that happens, files are thrown all over the file system. If it’s a 32 bit app, which most still are unfortunately on Windows, it puts some files in Program Files (x86), and then some files in the %APPDATA% directory somewhere, and god knows where else. Then it places some values in the registry, although nobody really knows where. This type of process makes it essentially impossible to put a Windows system back in its original state after installing something, if you so desire. The duplicate filesystem paths are another messy Windows design. You’ve got the aforementioned Program Files (x86) and Program Files. Then there is System32 and SysWow64, and my personal favorite ‘sysnative’. It’s just an ugly mess. On a Mac, apps are self-contained in an app bundle. Just drag the bundle to your /Applications folder, and you’re done. You want to remove it? Delete the app bundle. Settings that are normally stored in the registry on Windows, are stored in PLIST files on a Mac, which is just XML. A totally non-proprietary standard, that is simple to work with, and extremely effective. Nice and simple. Just as it should be. Design decisions like this, make a tremendous difference and there are so many of them, it’s difficult to list them all. As you get used to a Mac and its OS, you literally see them everywhere if you’re a power user. It’s just a superior operating system. Mac OS is built on top of FreeBSD, so along with all the great Apple OS features, of which there are many, you also get the Unix goodies baked in. Python, Bash, Ruby, Perl, Apache etc are all installed by default, and work out of the box along with all the other Unix command line utilities. None of them come installed on Windows. Each of them essentially treat Windows like a second class citizen anyway, and none work as well as they do on a Unix system even if you do go through the hassle of installing them. Admittedly, they all come on Linux too, but on Linux you still don’t get the great Apple features, such as Smart Folders, Automator, the Scripts menu, contextual Services, launchd, the Dock etc. There’s also the fact that if you want to do any iOS or Mac OS development, you need to have a mac. It’s unavoidable. That’s a very large area of innovation in and of itself. Huge in fact. Arguably, the most exciting areas of development of the last decade have happened on the Apple ecosystem, and with the fairly recent release of a truly outstanding programming language like Swift, that shows no signs of stopping. I would argue it’s the most exciting language out there today, and it’s certainly the fastest growing language. Apple hit it out of the park with Swift. They essentially took all the best features from the most popular languages, and packaged them into one powerful and cool language. The frameworks are also designed better on a mac, and any developer with Windows experience has gone through DLL hell as you try to fix version mismatch errors. These issues are essentially non-existent on Macs due to the superior design. The build quality of macs is also superior, and despite common perception, Macs actually aren’t more expensive than PCs. They just don’t offer a low-end product. If you spec out a PC with similar hardware, it’s basically the same price, and in many cases, actually more expensive. Then on top of that, you have to continue buying expensive OS upgrades from M$. Apple reliably releases a new OS at the same time each year, and it’s absolutely free. If you look at the couple most recent StackOverflow annual developer surveys, you’ll see that Mac OS is actually the most popular OS by developers now, and it’s due to the reasons I laid out here. Reliability, usability, intuitive design, Unix, and great design. Obviously people should use whatever they like, but to try and make the argument that Apple systems are somehow less functional couldn't be further from the truth. They're actually the most functional, which is why you see so many developers using them. Granted, many developers like Linux too, and I'm one of them. I have 2 Linux Virtual Machines on my iMac, and a Windows 10 VM. I only use them for specific purposes like testing though, and there is no system out there I'm more productive on than Mac OS. I'm not aware of single thing I can do on Windows that I can't do on Mac OS. I'm aware of many things I can do on Mac OS that I can't on Windows however. When you combine that additional functionality with the superior design, and it's a no-brainer.

This is a tough one. Any way I answer, someone will disagree with me - with a perfectly valid reason. However… In my experience, yes. The majority of Apple users are less “tech savvy”. Even much less. Yes. I would also agree that Windows/Android users tend to know more about the nuts and bolts behind the GUI. But that is not in any way a knock on Apple. Quite the opposite. In fact, the question seems to miss a something “everyone” knows. Apple is intentionally famous for exactly that. Simple. User friendly. Millions buy Apple for precisely that reason! Because they don’t need to know any tech to do what they want. A child can edit video, or create an awesome presentation. An 80 year old grandparent can pick up their iPhone when it makes a noise - and be in a Facetime with their 6 year old grandchild. Neither one has to know anything about tech. That isn’t “lesser utility”! It’s far more.  And then, when you get to the 5% or so who are very tech savvy, the picture changes again. When you have experience with (and background knowledge of) many OS’s, you might intentionally chose the one that allows you to get your job done with the least fuss. Or you might (as for many programmers) need/want capabilities that only the “user friendly” OS has. Like most gamers, I’m mostly a Windows and Android guy. I’ve run some servers on Linux, and I support some clients on Apple, but I’m still not as comfortable in *nix land. (Yes I do know Android is *nix.) But although I am more at home in Redmond territory, and OS X and IOS often feel confining to me… I have an abiding respect for most technology born in Cupertino. My disgust and revulsion for the demon iTunes is an exception, of course.

Steve Jobs has made it clear from the start: he wanted a “closed end” line of products. This is a fancy term for “black box”. You know how it works from the outside but you don’t really know how it works from the inside. From the end-user’s perspective, this is great. I don’t need the headache. The thing is working. Fullstop. Apple’s products are closed source (Edit: not completely true for OSX, as pointed out by User-12670461892230288093. Thanks!), same as Microsoft’s. Why is it working for Apple but not the same for Microsoft? For one, Apple provides both hrdware and software. When you design your own hardware, it is easy to write fully compatible software for it. Another thing that tops Apple is the high standard of their customer support. When you have excellent support, you don’t bother knowing the details. Why should you? Someone else is being paid for fixing your broken desktop. People like easiness. In GNU/Linux, we often write shell scripts to automate everyday repeated tasks for users. We hate to admit it, but we are also trying to ease the end-user’s experience. The general perception is that a tech savvy user is one who works with the command line and hates GUI. Under Mac and Windows you usually don’t fiddle around with the command line, you don’t need to. Even under GNU/Linux we mostly use a virtual terminal under X. Very few (mostly server admins) use the true shell. All in all, it depends on how deep you want to penetrate inside the system. The command line is available everywhere, you just don’t need (or want) to use it much.

Operating Systems – Does it matter what you use? Let’s face it.. most computer users these days know nothing about computers or the way things work. They use it for simple tasks and they just want to get things done. If the computer that they are using is able to perform the task that they want to accomplish, they’re content with it. Then there are the others who need to have the latest and greatest. These are the ones who believe in the hype or the next fad. If it is an Apple device, they will get that. Mostly you find these people are die-hard fans to specific brand or tech. I’m not talking about Apple users alone. I am talking about everyone in general. You find that quite a few developers are using Macbooks these days. Considering they are usually the most tech savvy people of all, I would say that Apple users are actually more tech savvy than the rest. So to answer your question… Why do users pay for Apple products with lesser utility? Are they less informed or less tech savvy? In truth.. No. It is because they are well informed on the subject, they choose Apple products. They want a machine that is reliable and usable. And in most cases feel that the high price is worth it.

Hello, Apple products have always been and are right now products for mainstream consumers. That doesn't mean it is made for least tech savvy . They sell products designed to have wide appeal. Macs were about making computers for more than the tech geeks that used dos. They attempt to make products that are easily approachable and logical to both the tech savvy and unsavvy, hence the phrase "it just works." It's why they have uniformity standards in their apps. They are trying not to confuse people. Well it doesn't just have to work for the techy. They will tackle many steps and minutia that mainstream consumer simply won't. But worrying about if you're "tech" enough buy apple is a silly context.

Disclaimer: I personally dislike Apple products myself, and have no actual data whatsoever to support these claims. In high school and so far in college, most of my peers use Macbooks and iPhones. I’m using Android phones, a Windows laptop, and a computer I hobbled together using scrap parts. I used to ask people why they insisted on $600 iPhones while my Android cost 1/6 and did most of the same things, and used Macbooks costing double my laptop cost. I know of other computer people like myself who love Macs, and I also know of idiots who use Windows. Trying to define everyone who uses Macs as dumb or otherwise is kind of tricky. Lots of Mac users who are less tech savvy use it because it’s simple and doesn’t break as often. However, that is not the sole reason people use Macs. I do know there was a study done that found Mac uses were more stuck up than Window users. So… Do what you want with that.

There is a huge contingent of hard-core technologists that use Apple products. They insist that Apple is superior. The same can be said for Linux and Microsoft. They are all right and the choices are all good. They all accomplish the same thing. What this boils down to is which one “clicks” with you. I like vanilla icecream, you like chocolate. It's as simple as that.
